qas.question: What Christian saint was also an Umayyad administrator?
What tax collectors did the Umayyads often leave in place after they conquered regions?
In addition to criticism received for employing non-Muslims, for what notable reason did some Muslims criticize the Umayyads?

answers.text: not reducing the taxes of the people who converted to Islam

plausible_answers.text: non-Muslim, former Roman administrators in their government

qas.question: What did many Muslims praise the Umayyads for?
Who removed the people's political representatives as they took over?
What was the Central government not paid for?
What did many Muslim cities use some of their taxes for?
Who reduced the taxes of the people who converted to Islam?

context: Many Muslims criticized the Umayyads for having too many <b3_0>non-Muslim, former Roman administrators in their government<b3_0/>. St <a0_0>John of Damascus<a0_0/> was also a high administrator in the Umayyad administration. As <b4_0>the Muslims<b4_0/> took over cities, they left the peoples political representatives and the <a1_0>Roman<a1_0/> tax collectors and the administrators. The taxes to the central government were calculated and negotiated by the peoples political representatives. The Central government got paid for the <b5_0>services it provided<b5_0/> and the local government got the money for the services it provided. Many Christian cities also used some of the taxes on <b6_0>maintain their churches<b6_0/> and run their own organizations. Later the <b7_0>Umayyads<b7_0/> were criticized by some Muslims for <a2_0>not reducing the taxes of the people who converted to Islam<a2_0/>. These new converts continues to pay the same taxes that were previously negotiated.
